name: The Adventure Phase
description:
Playing an Adventure

Adventures are pre-packaged, narrative experiences that allow you and your friends to play cooperatively without a Game Master. Each Adventure is a curated deck of cards that guides the story and generates encounters.

Setup

  1. Choose an Adventure: The group selects an Adventure Card. This card provides the story's premise and lists the other cards needed.
  2. Build the Adventure Deck: Following the Adventure Card's instructions, gather and stack the specified Quest, Event, and NPC cards. This deck is placed face-down.

How to Play

  1. Begin the Adventure: The players read the first card of the Adventure Deck to receive their starting objective.
  2. Travel and Explore: Quest cards will direct the party to a specific Region or Location card. The party performs a Journey Roll to travel between locations.
  3. Resolve Encounters: Upon arriving at a Location, a Timed Scene begins. Players set up the encounter as described on the Location card.
  4. Complete Objectives: Each Quest Card has a clear 'Progression' goal. Once the players achieve this goal, they follow the card's instructions.
  5. Draw the Next Card: Upon completing a Quest's progression, the players discard it and draw the next card from the Adventure Deck, continuing the story.

name: Location Exploration & Timed Scenes
description:
Timed Scenes

When a Quest card directs you to a Location, a timed scene begins. This is used for combat, complex traps, and other situations where turn order is important.

Setup

  1. Read the Location Card. Place the map tiles as described.
  2. Place all specified Enemy Creatures, Terrain, and other objects on the map.
  3. All players and creatures roll 1d20 for Initiative to determine the turn order for the round.

Rounds & Turns

A Round is a 6-second period where everyone takes one turn in initiative order. On your turn, you can perform one Action and one Movement. You also have one Reaction to use per round, which refreshes at the start of your turn.

name: Your Turn & Actions
description:
Your Turn in a Timed Scene

On your turn, you can take two Actions. You also have one Reaction to use per round, which refreshes at the start of your turn.

Action Pool

You can use your two Actions for any combination of the following:

  • Ability Action: Use a move like Hack & Slash, Volley, or any Feature that states it requires an Action.
  • Movement Action: Move a number of squares up to your SPEED. You can use both of your actions to Move, effectively 'dashing'.

Example: You could use one action to Move and a second action to Hack & Slash, or use both actions to cast two different spells (if their descriptions allow).

name: Journeys
description:
Journeys

When a Quest Card instructs you to travel to a new location, the party must make a Journey Roll.

  1. The party nominates one character as the Navigator.
  2. The Navigator rolls 1d20 + their WIS or INT modifier.

Outcomes

  • On a 16+: A swift and fortunate journey. Draw a card from the Blessings Deck and resolve its effect upon arrival.
  • On a 9-15: A successful but taxing journey. Each character arrives at the new location with either 1d4 fewer HP or 1 fewer MP/SP (player's choice).
  • On a 1-8: A perilous journey. Draw a card from the Hazards Deck and resolve its effects immediately.
Character abilities and items (like Travel Form or Mounts) may modify the Journey Roll or its outcome.

name: Adventure Actions
description:
Adventure Actions

Outside of combat, you use specific actions to interact with the environment. Each action requires a roll, with outcomes defined by the card you are interacting with.

Explore

When a card text mentions a general point of interest ('a crumbling wall', 'a strange marking'), a character can use their Action to Explore it. The card will specify the roll needed.

Investigate

Some cards have specific, marked points of interest. An adjacent character may use their Action to Investigate. The card provides the specific roll and outcomes.

Roll Outcomes for Explore & Investigate

  • On a 16+ (High Hit): You succeed with an added benefit. The card will detail the reward or bonus (e.g., 'You find the lever and gain +3 forward.').
  • On a 9-15 (Medium Hit): You succeed, but with a minor cost or complication. The card will specify what it is (e.g., 'You find the lever, but it is rusty and makes a loud noise.').
  • On a 1-8 (Low Hit): You fail and trigger a Peril. The card will have a specific 'Peril:' entry that you must resolve immediately (e.g., 'Peril: You trigger a poison dart trap. Take 1d6 HD.').

Influence

When an NPC Card is in play, you can use your Action to Influence them. The outcomes for this action, including success and failure, are described on the NPC card itself.

name: Creature AI & Behavior
description:
Creature AI & Behavior

Creatures get two Actions per turn and act automatically based on an AI card determined by their Intelligence (INT) score. Follow the steps on the appropriate AI card exactly.

Creature Actions

Creatures can use their actions to perform any ability listed on their card or to use Basic Actions (Hack & Slash, Shove, Grab, Disarm, Defend) just like players.

Humanoid Ranged Attacks

All creatures with the 'Humanoid' type are assumed to carry simple thrown weapons. They can always use the Volley basic action. Non-Humanoid creatures must have a specific ranged ability on their card to attack from a distance.

Determining Actions

On its turn, a creature follows the step-by-step instructions on its AI Card to determine its target and actions for the turn.

name: AI: Low Intelligence (Bestial)
description:
AI for Creatures with INT less than 0

These creatures act on pure instinct, focusing on the most immediate threat.

Turn Sequence:

  1. Can it Act?: If the creature is Stunned or otherwise incapacitated, its turn ends.
  2. Determine Target: Its target is the closest character. If there's a tie, it targets the one with the lowest current HP.
  3. Use Ranged Ability?: Can the creature use a ranged ability on its target from its current square? If YES, it uses its first Action to use the first available ranged ability on its card (alphabetically). It then uses its second Action to Defend. Its turn is now over. If NO, proceed to step 4.
  4. Roll for Behavior (d6):
    • 1-4 (Aggressive Assault): The creature will use its Actions to move and attack.
      • First Action: Use a Movement Action to move towards its target. If it ends adjacent, proceed to Second Action. If it does not end adjacent, its Second Action is also a Movement Action towards the target.
      • Second Action (if adjacent): Use the first available melee ability on its card (alphabetically). If none, it uses Hack & Slash.
    • 5-6 (Reckless Charge): The creature is singularly focused. It uses both of its Actions as Movement Actions, moving as far as possible towards its target.

name: AI: Medium Intelligence (Cunning)
description:
AI for Creatures with INT of 0 or 1

These creatures have a basic understanding of tactics and will try to exploit obvious disadvantages.

Turn Sequence:

  1. Can it Act?: If the creature is Stunned or otherwise incapacitated, its turn ends.
  2. Determine Target: Its target is the closest character with at least one negative Condition. If no character has a Condition, it targets the closest character. Tiebreaker: lowest current HP.
  3. Use Ranged Ability?: Can it use a ranged ability on its target from its current square? If YES, it uses its first Action for that ability and its second Action to Defend. Its turn ends. If NO, proceed to step 4.
  4. Roll for Behavior (d6):
    • 1-3 (Exploit Weakness): It uses its first Action to Move towards its target. For its second Action, it uses the first available ability that inflicts a Condition. If it has no such ability, it uses the first available melee ability alphabetically (or Hack & Slash).
    • 4-5 (Disrupt): It uses its first Action to Move adjacent to its target. For its second Action, it will use the first Basic Action available from this list, in order: Shove, Disarm, Grab. If it cannot, it will Hack & Slash.
    • 6 (Defensive): It uses its first Action to Defend. It uses its second Action to Move away from the character with the highest STR.

name: AI: High Intelligence (Mastermind)
description:
AI for Creatures with INT of 2 or higher

These creatures are highly intelligent, focusing on eliminating the most vulnerable threats and controlling the battlefield.

Turn Sequence:

  1. Can it Act?: If the creature is Stunned or otherwise incapacitated, its turn ends.
  2. Determine Target: Its target is the character with the lowest current HP. Tiebreaker: the closest character.
  3. Use Ranged Ability?: Can it use a ranged ability on its target? If YES, it will use its first Action to Move to a square with cover if possible, while staying in range. It uses its second Action to use the ranged ability with the highest damage die (e.g., d10 > d8). If it was already in range and cover, it uses its first Action for the ranged ability and its second to Defend. After this, its turn ends. If NO, proceed to step 4.
  4. Roll for Behavior (d6):
    • 1-3 (Eliminate the Weakest): It uses its first Action to Move to its target. It uses its second Action to perform the ability with the highest single-target damage die. If tied, it uses the first alphabetically.
    • 4-5 (Control the Battlefield): It uses its first Action to use the first available ability that targets an area (AoE) or inflicts Stunned, Immobilized, or Confused. It will position AoE abilities to hit the most characters while avoiding its allies. It uses its second Action to Move away from the nearest character.
    • 6 (Strategic Repositioning): The creature prioritizes its own safety. It uses its first Action to Move to the nearest square with cover. It uses its second Action to Defend.

name: Downtime Phase
description:
Time Off (Downtime)

When the party completes an Adventure and spends 1 week in a safe area, each character chooses one downtime activity:

  • Work: Gain gold equal to (CAR + another ability of your choice) x 1d10.
  • Recover: Restore all HP, MP, and SP to maximum and clear all conditions.
  • Purchase Treasure Booster: Spend 100 gold to buy a Treasure Booster Pack (6 Item cards: 1 Uncommon, 5 Common).
  • Deck Management: Freely swap cards between your Active and Side Decks, and re-devote your Crystals to different cards.

name: Character Progression
description:
Advancement (Spending XP)

During the Downtime Phase, you can spend XP to acquire new cards for your character.

  • 5 XP: Purchase Hero Booster Pack. This pack contains 6 non-item/hireling cards, with one guaranteed Character card and one guaranteed Destiny card. Add these new cards to your Active or Side Deck.

name: Character & Player Decks
description:
Character & Player Decks

As a player, you have a master collection of all the cards you've acquired. Your current character's cards are in your Active Deck. All other cards you own are in your Side Deck.

  • Active Deck: These are the cards that define your current character. They are 'in play' and their abilities can be used.
  • Side Deck: Cards not in your Active Deck. These cards cannot be used, but they are safe. They can be used to build a new character if your current one dies.
  • Character Death: When a character dies, all cards in their Active Deck are lost forever. Your Side Deck remains, forming the foundation for your next character.

name: Deckbuilding Rules
description:
Deckbuilding Rules

An Active Deck has a limit on certain card types to define your character's core identity.

Unique Card Types

A deck can't have more than a single card of each of the following types:

  • Personality
  • Culture
  • Species
  • Background
  • Family
  • Friends
  • Enemies
  • Drawback
  • Destiny

Exceptions

You may include multiple copies of the following card types in your deck, as these represent skills and gear acquired over time:

  • Features
  • Trainings
  • Items
  • Hirelings

name: Character Creation
description:
Character Creation

To create a new character, you build your starting deck by opening two booster packs:

  • Hero Booster Pack: This pack contains 6 cards. One card its always a Character card, a Destiny card and the remaining 5 are random cards that are not items or hirelings.
  • Treasure Booster Pack: This pack contains 6 Item cards, which includes 1 Uncommon and 5 Common Items.

Your starting Active Deck is built from this initial pool of cards, following all Deckbuilding Rules.

name: Crystals & Attunement
description:
Crystals & Attunement

Many cards in your Active Deck have a `provides` field, which lists colored crystals. These crystals form your character's Crystal Pool.

Devoting Crystals

Some cards (like Features and Items) have abilities that `require` crystals to be used. During the Downtime Phase, you may devote crystals from your pool to these cards. A devoted crystal is 'locked in' to that card, enabling its abilities. You can have un-devoted crystals in your pool, but they serve no function until they are devoted.

You can change how your crystals are devoted whenever you are in the Downtime Phase.

name: Roll Results
description:
Roll Results

When a move is triggered, roll 1d20 plus the appropriate modifier. The outcomes are as follows:

  • Low Hit (1-8): Your action has a minimal effect and usually comes with a complication or a negative consequence.
  • Medium Hit (9-15): You succeed, but with a lesser effect or a partial success.
  • High Hit (16+): You succeed fully, often with an additional beneficial effect.

On advantage, roll 2d20 and pick the best result. On disadvantage, roll 2d20 and pick the worst result.

name: Social Combat
description:
Social Combat

Some encounters are a battle of wits and willpower, not swords and spells. These are resolved through Social Combat, a timed scene where the goal is to overcome an opponent's resolve.

  • Winning and Losing: In Social Combat, your SP (Social & Sanity Points) act as your health pool. You use abilities like Parley or other features that deal SD (Social Damage) to reduce your opponent's SP. When an NPC's SP reaches 0, they are 'defeated'—convinced, intimidated, or broken. The NPC's card will describe the outcome. If a player's SP reaches 0, they are socially defeated, unable to influence the scene further and may suffer a narrative consequence.
  • Turns and Actions: Social Combat follows the same turn structure as physical combat (Initiative, Action, Movement). NPCs in social combat will have a simple AI script on their card dictating their actions.

name: Combat on the Grid
description:
Combat on the Grid

When a Quest or Event card triggers a hostile encounter, a Timed Scene begins on a grid. The Location Card defines the size and layout of this grid.

Setup

  1. Place the Location: Lay out the grid as defined by the Location card.
  2. Place Terrain: Place any Terrain Cards (e.g., 'Mine Cart', 'Wall') on their specified grid squares. These cards modify the squares they are on.
  3. Place Creatures & Characters: Place the cards for each creature and character on the grid at their starting positions as described by the Location card. This shows everyone's position and facing.

Once setup is complete, the first round of combat begins, following the Initiative & Turn Order rules.

name: Initiative & Turn Order
description:
Initiative & Turn Order

Combat follows a 'zig-zag' initiative system that alternates between player and creature turns. No initiative roll is required.

Turn Order

The turn order for each round is fixed: PLAYER -> CREATURE -> PLAYER -> CREATURE -> ...

  • Player Turns: During a PLAYER slot, the player group decides which one of their characters will act. Each character may only take one turn per round.
  • Creature Turns: During a CREATURE slot, the next creature in the activation order takes its turn.

Creature Activation Order

Creatures are activated in a 'zig-zag' order, determined by their position on the grid. At the start of each round, find the un-activated creature in the top-most row. If there is a tie, pick the one left-most. This is the first creature to act. For the next creature turn, you find the next un-activated creature by scanning from that one's position, row by row, left to right. Once all creatures have acted, the round ends and the activation order resets.

Surprise Round

Some Event or Quest cards may grant a Surprise Round. If this happens, one side (usually the players) gets to take a full round of turns before normal initiative begins.

name: Wall
description:
Represents impassable structures like stone walls, cave-ins, or dense, impenetrable magical barriers.

Properties

  • Impassable: Squares with a Wall cannot be moved into or through by any means.
  • Blocks Line of Sight: A Wall blocks line of sight for attacks and abilities.
  • Solid: Creatures cannot be Pushed, Pulled, or otherwise moved into a square containing a Wall. If a forced movement effect would cause a creature to collide with a Wall, the movement stops and any relevant collision effects (like Crush) are triggered.

name: Last Breath
description:
Last Breath

When you are dying (at 0 HP), you glimpse the Black Gates of Death. Roll+COS.

  • On a 16+: You cheat death and stabilize at 1 HP, but are Weakened.
  • On a 9-15: Death offers you a bargain. Draw a Bargain Card. If you accept the terms, you return to life as described. If you refuse, you die.
  • On a 1-8: Your fate is sealed. You die. Your Active Deck is destroyed, but your Side Deck remains for your next character.

name: Hack & Slash
description:
Hack & Slash

When you use your Action to attack an enemy in melee, roll+STR.

  • On a 16+: You deal your full HD. If your DEX is greater than the target's DEX, you can also choose to apply the Weakened condition for 1 round.
  • On a 9-15: You deal your full HD.
  • On a 1-8: You deal half your HD (rounded down), but your wild swing leaves you open; the enemy gains +3 forward against you.

name: Volley
description:
Volley

When you use your Action to launch a ranged attack, roll+DEX.

  • On a 16+: You have a clear shot and deal your full HD.
  • On a 9-15: You deal your full HD, but you must choose one complication: move to a dangerous position; expend extra ammo; or hit an unintended target (as determined by the nearest creature to the target).
  • On a 1-8: You deal half your HD, but your shot gives away your position, attracting unwanted attention.

name: Defy Danger
description:
Defy Danger

When you act despite an imminent threat (often triggered by an Event, Hazard, or Terrain card), say how you are dealing with it and roll the relevant stat (STR, DEX, etc.).

  • On a 16+: You succeed and overcome the danger.
  • On a 9-15: You succeed, but face a lesser cost, a hard choice, or a lingering consequence.
  • On a 1-8: You stumble. The danger strikes you before you can fully act, but you partially succeed or lessen the blow. The card will describe the costly success.

name: Defend
description:
Defend

When you use your Action to stand in defense of a person or place, roll+CON.

  • On a 16+: Hold 3.
  • On a 9-15: Hold 2.
  • On a 1-8: Hold 1, but you also become Weakened for 1 round.

Spend your hold 1-for-1 to: Redirect an attack to yourself; halve an attack's damage; or grant an ally +3 forward against an attacker.

name: Forced Movement & Positioning
description:
Forced Movement & Positioning

Many abilities can move creatures around the grid. This movement does not provoke reactions. A creature cannot be moved into a square occupied by a solid object or another creature of the same size or larger.

  • Push X: Move the target X squares directly away from you.
  • Pull X: Move the target X squares directly towards you.
  • Lift X: Move the target X squares vertically into the air. If the effect ends while they are airborne, they fall.
  • Crush X: This is a special Push. If the target's movement is blocked by a solid surface (like a wall), they immediately stop and take 1d6 HD for every remaining square of movement.

name: Physics & Environment
description:
Collisions, Falling & Environment

The environment is a weapon. Use it to your advantage.

  • Collision: If a creature is Pushed or Pulled into another creature's space, both creatures stop moving and take 1d6 HD.
  • Falling Damage: A creature takes 1d6 HD for every 2 squares they fall, to a maximum of 10d6.
  • Falling On Creatures: If a creature falls onto a square occupied by another, the creature below must make a DEX roll to avoid the impact. On a failure, both creatures take the falling damage. If the falling creature is significantly larger, the creature below takes double damage and is knocked prone.

name: Conditions
description:
Conditions

When a character is affected by a condition, they suffer its effects until it is removed or its duration expires. The same condition from multiple sources does not stack.

  • Blinded: You have disadvantage on all actions that require sight. Attacks against you have advantage.
  • Charmed: You cannot attack the creature that charmed you. The charmer has advantage on all SP-based actions against you.
  • Confused: At the start of your turn, roll a d6. On a 1-2, you do nothing. On a 3-4, you attack the nearest creature (friend or foe). On a 5-6, you may act normally.
  • Deafened: You automatically fail any action that requires hearing.
  • Frightened: You have disadvantage on all actions while the source of your fear is within line of sight. You cannot willingly move closer to the source of your fear.
  • Immobilized: Your SPEED becomes 0. You cannot be moved by Push, Pull, Lift, or Crush effects.
  • Poisoned: You take a specified amount of ongoing HD at the start of your turn.
  • Stunned: You cannot take actions or reactions. Attacks against you have advantage.
  • Taunted: You must use your action to attack the creature that taunted you, if possible.
  • Weakened: You have disadvantage on your next action, attack, or move.

name: Movement & Positioning
description:
Movement & Positioning

You can use your Movement on your turn to move up to your SPEED. This can be broken up before and after your Action.

  • Difficult Terrain: Costs 2 squares of movement for every 1 square entered.
  • Stand Up: Standing from prone costs half your movement for the turn.
  • Provoking Attacks: Voluntarily moving out of an enemy's melee range provokes an Attack of Opportunity from them.

name: Attack of Opportunity
description:
Attack of Opportunity

When an enemy you are engaged with in melee voluntarily moves out of your reach, you can use your Reaction to make a single melee attack against them. This attack happens immediately before they leave your reach. Forced movement does not provoke this reaction.

name: Disengage
description:
Disengage

When you use your Action to carefully withdraw from combat, you can move up to half your SPEED (rounded down). This movement does not provoke Attacks of Opportunity.

name: Shove
description:
Shove

When you use your Action to shove a creature your size or smaller, roll+STR.

  • On a 16+: You succeed. Choose one: Push 3 the target, or knock the target prone.
  • On a 9-15: You succeed, but can only Push 2.
  • On a 1-8: You manage to Push 1, but you also stumble and are knocked prone.

name: Grab
description:
Grab

When you use your Action to grab a creature your size or smaller, roll+STR.

  • On a 16+: You successfully grab the target. They are Immobilized. If their STR is less than your STR, you can also move them at half your speed.
  • On a 9-15: You grab them, but have a poor grip. They are Immobilized but can use their action to make an opposed STR roll to escape.
  • On a 1-8: You only manage to grab a piece of their clothing, making them Weakened for 1 round.

name: Disarm
description:
Disarm

When you use your Action to disarm an opponent, roll+DEX.

  • On a 16+: You knock their weapon from their grasp. It lands 1d4 squares away in a random direction.
  • On a 9-15: You knock the weapon loose, and it falls into their square.
  • On a 1-8: You only manage to jar their grip; they have disadvantage on their next attack.

name: Delay Action
description:
Delay Action

On your turn, you can state a specific, observable trigger you are waiting for. If that trigger occurs before your next turn, you can perform your action as a Reaction. If the trigger does not occur by the end of the round, you can take your action then.

name: Sanity
description:
Sanity

Witnessing otherworldly horrors or learning forbidden truths can drain your Social Points (SP). Certain Event or Creature cards will call for a Sanity Check.

  • Sanity Check: When prompted, roll+WIS. On a 16+, you steel your nerve. On a 9-15, you are shaken and lose 1 SP. On a miss, you lose 1d6 SP and may gain the Frightened or Confused condition as described on the card.

name: Encumbrance
description:
Encumbrance

Your Load is equal to 10 + your COS score. While carrying weight up to your Load, you are fine. When carrying weight greater than your Load, you have disadvantage on all physical moves (STR, DEX, CON).

name: Creatures
description:
Creatures

Creatures are the denizens of the world, from lowly beasts to powerful monsters. They follow the same basic rules as characters but are controlled by a simple AI.

Color Identity & Power Level

The crystals displayed on a card represent its thematic identity and power.

  • Color Identity: The crystal's color (e.g., Red, Green, Black) gives the card its identity. Certain abilities may reference this, such as 'Deal +2 damage to GREEN creatures'.
  • Power Level: The number of crystals indicates the creature's overall power. This is used for certain character abilities (e.g., 'Tame a creature of Power Level 2 or less').

name: Stats and Crystals Legend
description:
Stats & Crystals Legend

The icons on each card provide a quick reference for its stats and crystal properties. Here is what each symbol represents:

Primary Stats

These define a character's core resources and combat prowess.

HP (Health Points): Your physical vitality. If it reaches 0, you are dying.
MP (Mana Points): Your magical energy, used to cast spells and power mystical abilities.
SP (Social & Sanity Points): Your mental fortitude and social stamina, used for psychic powers and exerting influence.
HD (Physical Damage): The base damage die for your physical attacks, like swinging a sword.
MD (Magical Damage): The base damage die for your magical attacks and spells.
SD (Social Damage): The base damage die for your social or psychic attacks that target the mind or spirit.

Secondary Stats

These stats govern movement and physical capabilities.

Armor: Reduces incoming physical damage (HD).
Speed: The number of squares you can move in a turn.

Abilities

Your character's six core attributes, used for making rolls.

STR (Strength): Physical power, athletics, and melee combat.
DEX (Dexterity): Agility, stealth, and ranged combat.
COS (Constitution): Health, endurance, and resisting physical hardship.
INT (Intelligence): Logic, knowledge, and arcane spellcasting.
WIS (Wisdom): Perception, intuition, and divine or natural magic.
CAR (Charisma): Force of personality, persuasion, and social skills.

Crystals

Crystals represent a card's thematic essence and are used to power certain abilities.

Red (Might): Represents physical power, rage, and martial prowess.
Green (Hunt): Represents tracking, survival, and ranged combat.
Emerald (Nature): Represents the natural world, druidic magic, and healing.
Orange (Primal): Represents shamanism, elemental fury, and savage strength.
Cerulean (Arcane): Represents raw magical power, knowledge, and sorcery.
Purple (Influence): Represents social skills, psychic power, and performance.
White (Faith): Represents divine healing, holy power, and devotion.
Blue (Order): Represents protection, justice, and tactical command.
Black (Shadow): Represents stealth, poison, necromancy, and subterfuge.
Gold (Ingenuity): Represents invention, commerce, and craftsmanship.

name: Titles & Legacy
description:
Titles & Legacy

Titles are unique cards awarded for making significant, story-altering decisions during an adventure. They do not take up a slot in your Active Deck and are considered a permanent part of your party's legacy.

How Titles Work

A Title provides a persistent narrative effect that can be invoked in future adventures. The Title card will specify a trigger and its outcome.

Example: A Quest card might say, 'If any character has the Hero of Stonebridge title, they automatically succeed on the Influence action with the town guard.'

These cards represent your group's reputation and the impact you've had on the world, creating a continuous story across different adventures.
